Y-n38ivkjjq-cmdMC88dRA.text: Have been wanting to check out this place for an American-style breakfast for a while. Visited recently and found it disappointing. The two of us had the Lumberjack breakfast + coffee + orange juice, and the total came to a whopping £30. Seems a bit steep, considering that it's just 2 eggs, 2 rashers (not smoked streaky bacon like it should be), and 3 thin pancakes that tasted mysteriously of apple and were served with Golden Syrup instead of maple. While the pancakes weren't bad, they just weren't pancakes in the "classic american diner" sense, which is how they are billed. At least give us some maple-flavoured syrup! Otherwise there's really nothing american about it. The "bottomless" coffee is only on request. The wait staff do not come by and offer more if you don't ask.

0GD_ydjqX__SL6usmhpzMA.text: Absolutely great food!  Just like a diner at home in the US and the burgers are probably some of the best that I've had in London.  A group of 4 of us went on a Friday night after leaving Bar 55 and everybody had something that they loved.  We were told at the door that we had to wait 10-15 minutes for a table for four and happily stayed to do so.  At the end of our meal, the hostess felt so bad for the wait that she brought out a free cappuccino for everyone.  Perfect end to a great evening.

K_qHvteGIqhTXaCVt_xc0w.text: Visited just before midday on a Saturday; The Diner is clean, there was music in the background but you can still comfortably talk to each other. We were seated right away, although during our meal we over heard people being told that there is a half an hour wait for a table. They apparently operated a service where by they would text your phone when your table is ready, but we must have come at a good time. We ordered the Hungry Man Breakfast and a Lumberjack Breakfast, a coke and a still water which came up to £24.98 and it came slowly at that. The meal itself was unfortunately neither quality nor quantity and I don't think I'll be hurrying back any time soon, certainly not at that price. On the other hand the atmosphere was good but the end of the meal I was given the wrong bill - a more expensive one from another table. So by the end although it looks promising, The Diner has more downs than ups.

rQGE0k25QlaUAF6Noy4scw.text: A world apart from it's Shoreditch site this place is worth going to. Better to go early mid week in order to avoid the Camden hustle. Breakfasts are great. Their Breakfast Burrito and Huevo Rancheros are all the rave. Awesome Jack Daniels and Peanut Butter milkshakes are a definite must. Good and child friendly friendly service.

qnKfQgjDsDk6lFVHjff7-Q.text: The Diner in Camden is a new wave version of the traditional American diner.  Instead of playing cheesy music from the 1950s they play the Smiths.  The waitresses are ultra vivacious and fashionable with indie crew cuts and super hot tattoos and they serve cheeseburgers with finesse.  The décor is so cool.  The walls are black and red and there are lots of retro pictures and mirrors on the wall.  Dining here is such a fun experience.  It renovates tradition and makes the past feel so vibrant.  Atmosphere isn't the only thing The Diner's good at; the food is delicious.  So come in, let your hair down and join the headbanger's cheeseburger ball.

photos.caption: Photo of The Diner - London, United Kingdom

GR-xyf250bWe3OpoH3irAw.text: Good old-fashioned diner food here. I think you'd struggle to find something healthy on the menu, but if you're nursing a hangover, this place could be your best friend. It gets busy at the weekends--we go quite a bit after the lunch rush so we don't have to wait.

mAjnABmOHXd8JlaMRZxdzQ.text: The Diner in Camden is the most recent in the restaurant chain's line of American style diners around London. In my opinion, it is their best. It isn't slow like their Old Street branch and it isn't lacking in atmosphere like their Ganton Street branch.  Situated in the midst of Camden's hellish main street, The Diner provides a welcome escape. The service was very quick as we only waited 5 minutes,  and the food and drinks were very good-we had milkshakes, onion rings and hotdogs. It was a perfect place to take kids.

photos.caption: Photo of The Diner - London, United Kingdom

IhOQ6aBNm2B4QXe5ZpVbtw.text: I was surprised to learn that there was a diner in Camden. I was quite keen to go to the one in Soho the other night, but my idea was poo-pooed by the gang. However, I did manage to drag my poor, unsuspecting friend in last night since it was on the way home.I have to say I wasn't that impressed. Perhaps it's because I've lived in the States for too long so I'm pretty conditioned to how my chili hot dog should taste, and the consistency of my milkshake. I had a bacon double cheeseburger, and a beer, which came to about £9, but was pretty forgettable. The one member of staff was a little overworked so service wasn't tremendous. We did however sit next to some famous bloke from the TV, who supposedly lives in Camden and who my friend has a huge crush on, so this made her very happy indeed. I get the feeling that you'd be better off going to this diner's counterpart in Soho, where the decor is more in tune with original Americana and the atmosphere is more kicking.

PrhEan2ex-1sxrPRngUBMQ.text: What a rip off! Breakfasting in Camden has never been so pricey! 6.50 for eggs benedict, plus 2 quid for your tea and then they slap on a 12.5% service charge!! So you're talking a tenner each for what isn't really a massive breakfast. There are many better places to go round here, not least the Italian cafe just by Mornington Cresent station - where you get a huge full English with tea for 4.20!!

photos.caption: Photo of The Diner - London, United Kingdom

zQsFVy1BkKcUxEDt_JE8hA.text: I had great expectations for The Diner in Camden - after keenly watching its transformation from the sticky cesspit known as Arizona Bar - however despite making some fairly clear promises, it fails to deliver. Everything about the place cues your brain into thinking American style (although just as we walked in it seemed less 50's diner and more Ralph Bakshi?!), and yet unlike other businesses which operate the same facade (Ed's Easy Diner, Automatic, Johnny Rockets) it feels annoyingly English. Not that there's anything wrong with English (far from it!), but why buy into a look you can't carry through? I opted for the winningly greasy post-Friday-night combination of an omelette with ham & peppers, chocolate milkshake, and cheese fries to share with my learned colleague who was in a similar state to me. The omelette was insipid & perfunctory at best, the fries were incredibly greasy even without the contribution from the cheese, and the milkshake was similarly passable - nothing was bad as such, but nothing about the place made you want to go back there. Another way of saying it would be that the breakfasts weren't big enough to make you feel like you'd gotten value for money, but weren't tasty enough that you'd wished you'd been given more. Every forkful of the forgettable fare offered here made the pair of us wish we'd opted for going around the corner to Bar Solo instead. About the only thing we felt this place really had working in its favour was offering a place to sit down and chill out for a moment amid the lunacy of a Saturday in the heart of Camden.

rl9Oq4hlBi23CKNAKpNPnQ.text: Went there on a Saturday lunchtime (not advised) and had a burger and chips. I think a better time to visit, if at all, would probably be midweek, as the service was a little slow and it took a while to get seated. I liked the decor - as people have said already it's in a typical American diner style, and when I went the waitresses all seemed to be dressed in old-style outfits. I'm not entirely sure if that's their normal choice of clothes or if this is restaurant policy! The food itself was fine, although nothing special. Burger was far better than TGIs et al, chips were as you'd expect. My friends had an American breakfast (a bit small) and a hot dog (uninspired). For the money, I'd expect better, and there are loads of better alternatives.

zFEnWfIo8TsOWdvwYVswjg.text: Working in Camden, it is always exciting when a new restaurant opens. This was particularly true when the gross Arizona bar was replaced by the Diner, at a time when Camden was sorely missing the Hawley Arms. Oh what a disappointment the Diner turned out to be. The building itself is excellent with a very tasteful and comfy roof terrace. But sadly the food is lacklustre and over priced. If they would just knock their prices down and improve the quality, I would love to go back. But £4 for a milkshake is terrible. Thankfully the Hawley is back, for affordable tasy grub. And if you fancy splashing the cash, head to Hache on Inverness Street for a delicious burger. Diner: Must try harder. Please try harder.

aJz1jtw3LFKLPN6NxJh-bA.text: I have mixed feelings about this place. The food was good, and everyone enjoyed their milkshakes. The service however was less than good. We had to wait for over half an hour to get anything on the table, including a jug of water! Although the food was good, I don't think I'll want to go through the waiting pain again to get it.

uTbb6Q_2L92PH_-toq0TbQ.text: The food's alright. The terrace seating is pretty nice on a sunny day. But it's the milkshakes that bring all the boys to the yard.

cv60JAHoHnk0Ca4ken828A.text: The Diner is another foolish attempt made by whoever (it might not even be Americans behind it) to try and cut into our society with their fatty malingering food. I don't mind the food - hotdogs and burgers, what is really wrong with that? At £9-10, bloody everything. Dress it up, put it on a plate and what, it doesn't make a £2.50 meal four times as expensive. I wouldn't even bother to eat here, despite what appears to be an extensive menu, because they aren't worth you showing you support their business. Shouldn't try to rip us off should they!

Ia85pEitUUXENCyJxmoY5A.text: Nice place to have breakfast/brunch in camden. Nice food, nice ambience, crowd of young cool people. Very friendly staff and easy on the eye as well (that is worth half extra star) :) nice music sometime a bit too loud but that could be a sign of my old age :)))

2BINvuORlJV5SEvFzSFJgA.text: Yummy milkshakes. Great breakfast food. I usually prefer to eat down in the walk when in Camden but it's a good place for ex-pats of America to come to when feeling a little homesick.

AB3453x_gW3hQ4GahFZ9rQ.text: Tasty but way overpriced for what you get. Staff are a bit condescending too. For a tenner I would have expected a gourmet feast, not a single muffin, dry scrambled egg, hash browns and the smallest slice of bacon you've ever seen - plus a coke.

uEGThtN1-srZL7qGCpB_1g.text: Nice place, good decor, you should go once to see. However, the food isn't great and slightly overpriced. The big breakfast isn't nearly as big as billed!

U77XqfBb9yzbQpNIW5SLIg.text: Oh The Diner! I can't hate you, I'm always too grateful for your pancakes and bacon in the morning to hate you, or your crazy cool staff.I love booths, I really do. I like to sit in the with friends and pretend I'm in a movie. I can do that here, act like a twat and it's fine, because I fit in with everyone else, acting like a twat.If you want good greasy food that's a bit pricey but really tasty you can't really go wrong with The Diner. The even do boozy cocktails, if that floats your boat, oh and their Macaroni and Cheese is like sexy time. If you haven't figured this out already I have an unhealthy relationship with cheese. Fondue anyone?

t4g_90gPSt8zQhRneXezFQ.text: Food was terrible, greasy burgers, burritos sitting in pools of liquid. The staff could not be less interested. If you sit outside, you might as well be invisible.Favourite was when the waitress recommended not to have the normal burger as it was tastless.

8Kpo_Jldg5CeE11yaTKIpQ.text: The Diner in Camden is much like the Diner in Soho and Angel. You know exactly what you're going to get and there are scarcely any surprises. My dining experience recently was no different. They only thing i've noticed about the portion size at The Diner is that it is generally fairly average and leaves you wanting more, however, I decided to sample something new, The Breakfast Burrito. Now, I'm a HUGE fan of the one they do at the Breakfast Club, so they had a strong criteria to meet. You will be pleased to hear it met up to my standards, plus you get a side of beans and smashed avocado. For 8 nuggets you can't go wrong). The real things to sample there as always are the Shakes. At 5 squirrels a go they can seem expensive, but whatever magic they put in them, is totally worth it. There is outdoor seating and if they have the garden open on the top deck make sure you take advantage of the sun and eat up there. The outdoor tables are a little wobbly, so just don't jig about on them too much. Oh and should you leave your card there... don't get home before you realise. Sexy Rob

Bp_PnKVnmb4KizqeXeRsEA.text: I have been to a number of this chain and was expecting good things of the Camden branch. My usual venue of choice is Islington but we were here on a friends birthday meal.We arrived early evening and decided to go upstairs to the al-fresco area. This is an open rooftop area which suited some of the guests who are smokers. The service upstairs was, at first, the usual attentive and personable sort I normally associate with The Diner and as guests arrived they were dealt with in friendly and quick fashion by a charming waiter. However as the meal progressed it became clear that we were either in the middle of a shift change or the friendly waiter was best suited to downstairs. It also became clear that the upstairs area was closing. We managed to order our main courses and sides before he disappeared,The second waiter appeared personable once again but seems more than a little distracted. We ordered desserts and I ordered a hard shake. The desserts took more than a little time to arrive as we were informed the sundaes took up to 15 minutes to produce. We duly waited about 25 minutes and the waiter was nowhere to be seen to order another drinks round either. When he did arrive he unloaded the back of the tray first and left the sundaes at the front. As soon as he backed away they overbalanced and crashed to the floor. One of the guests jacket and chair was splattered by the ice cream and sauce and another shoes covered too. The waiter picked up the sundaes, apologised and ran off to get something to clean it with. He was gone about 5 minutes by which time we had already employed wet wipes. The 'replacement' sundaes arrived not 2 minutes later which leads me to believe that they were the original ones that had fallen topped off again. Still the guests ate them.However it wasn't until they had nearly finished the desserts that I had to collar the waiter to find out if my hard shake was coming at all. He duly informed me that it had 'gone through'. I politely pointed out that this doesn't mean I had it and he went to check. Another 5 minutes and it duly turned up meaning I had to hurry and finish as everyone else was ready to leave. Upon requesting the bill, not a single offer of apology was made as we paid and left. As I closed the door I resolved that I wouldn't return againThe two stars awarded were for the service and food quality before the shift change otherwise it would have been 1 star

hBa1B_ZMVPthKY73CSef9Q.text: Well it has been sometime since i last went to Camden, and on my expedition to my old home i found The Diner.We were kind of struggling to pick between this place and the one next door, both offering burgers; but as soon as i heard White Stripes coming out from the door my decision was made. (A not very foodie requirement, but i do love a bit of Alt music)Now this is where this place doesnt get 5 stars, the service is a little sucky; in particular from the Host, who doesnt seem to care, or hold himself in any sort of professional manner which is a little unusual. This may have been as it was very busy, but it still resonates as something i wouldnt want to experience again.The food!There are so many things on this menu i wanted to try! I would def recommend they have a selection of mini sliders on a platter as a new dish as one just is not enough!I settled for the whatever burger (cant remember its name) It was pretty much a big mac, except in the taste department, where it left its rival standing, although i think the burger pattie itself couldve done with a hit of seasoning during the cooking process. The burger sauce was delicious though i happily mopped up the falling out remnants with the sweet potato fries.Also i point you towards the milkshakes, they are a little expensive (maybe im just saying that as im used to Northern prices) but they are packed with taste.Again when it came to paying, or should i phrase it when they asked us to pay to turn over the table as quickly as possible, i wasnt a big fan.Great food, great drinks, great music and ambience. Not so great service, however as i pointed out before it was very busy.

tpZM_hREURpRbGAwrxKYuQ.text: Hmmm.... The Diner. So close. So much potential. So... average.A well seasoned visitor and once temporary resident of the USA, I feel I know my way around a diner menu. So I was happy to see some of the old classics on their (huge) list of offerings - massive milkshakes, corndogs, chilli fries, all day lumberjack breakfasts. Even Arizona Iced Teas (YUM)! Once you've got over the novelty of being in a replicated American diner in Camden though (or Soho or Islington for that matter), then you come to realise that the food isn't actually that great! Shame really.My cheesesteak (and it wasn't a cheesesteak... arrrggghhh) turned up just the right side of luke warm, and my chilli fries had perhaps, I like to think, been waiting for the perfect customer for, I dunno, a couple of hours? The milkshake was of course delicious, and I'm glad they've got that right. Peanut butter for an extra 50p? Yes please!I'd go again and hope I hit the place at a bad time on this occasion.Oh and who comes to a place like this to snog each others face off for, literally, 30mins? I'm not sure they came up for air once. Strrrrange.

ugezL4oeo4ShDPJPXsUY-A.text: i've been to the diner before a couple of years ago and remember being pretty unimpressed with the quality of the food, so i wasn't exactly over joyed to be coming here for some pre-gig food. that being said, it was actually pretty good. the service was great - the girls looking after us were very friendly and helpful, and made sure to check up on us regularly without being overbearing. the atmosphere inside is cosy and warm, with some dubious musical choices (whyyyy would you turn off death cab for cutie for ANY reason? much less to put something shit on. rude!)i ordered the small hot and spicy chicken wings with a side of sweet potato fries. the wings were actually pretty good - although not that hot and spicy - and a plentiful portion. the sweet potato fries were okay - nothing mind blowing, and i have had better in london, but definitely better than i can make. they were a large portion too, although for £3.30 i would expect them to be!my dining companions ordered a cheeseburger and a big humongous hot dog with fries and sweet potatoes as sides and they were both happy with what they got. i thought the burger and hot dog buns looked dry and pretty disappointing, but they didn't complain so maybe they weren't. i wouldn't rush back here, but it's definitely an okay option if you're in camden. i don't think there's a huge amount of choice for really good food round that way, so i always struggle when trying to think where to go.

c-L1fosohGXAzYgIE7rd1w.text: ''My milkshake brings all the boys to the yard,And their likeIt's better than yours,Damn right it's better than yours,I can teach you,But I have to charge.''It's their milkshakes (and JD hardshakes) that keeps me coming back to this Americana burger and fries joint. Chocolate & peanut butter FTW They are a bit pricey but considering they serve you the 'leftovers' you can usually get at least two glasses full :) The service is always good here too; fast and attentive to their customers. The place has a rocking soundtrack that doesn't sound like Grease (even though you feel like you have stepped into a 50s film set) and there are plenty of booths. Plus the upstairs deck is noice - a hidden beer garden in summer.Though I have to agree with the 3-star average rated by the rest of the Yelpers - as The Diner is fairly over priced for the food that you get. A tiny burger and a few french fries. But I guess you are paying for 'the experience' and it's the no-brainer appeal of the place that keeps me coming back (plus those shakes!).

pzhihDi3Cx7SkIic-XZY5Q.text: Not quite sure why I return here so often.  The food's really not all that great.  I guess it's because in some ways its a little slice of home.I think that Laura was spot on with references to terrible Mex with a sad excuse for salsa and dishes you could do better yourself at home (similar to generic american chains). Guess I'm always just expecting something more along the lines of a ma and pa diner.  Speaking of which, I need to finish my review of the Original Pantry Cafe in Los Angeles... Now THAT'S the kind of diner food-wise that I wish this Diner could be.Anyways, musics good, I love the decor, and I dig the staffs style (plus they don't make me feel awkward for ordering a bloody mary, and coffee, and juice, AND water with my breakfast).

hRyQ6DxpqI1oENasYTELtA.text: Finally an American restaurant that serves (closest) American food The resturant is placed perfectly off the busy high street. I like the idea of not having to look out of the window to witness all the dramas outside.The dim lit, leather booth interiors, swing music, gives it that smokey jazz atmosphere! The staff members are friendly and they look amazing, they remind me off the characters in Grease. Its a 3 course menu including side dishes. I've been there twice and first time round I wasnt impressed with the food I ordered..partly my fault as I was just tight with my budget 0_oI opted for the fish burger, the bread was hard and fish was slightly dry. However it did not stop me from giving them the benefit of the doubtSecond time round I decided to get out of my comfort zone and opted for the corn dogs with the chunky chips. Oh man the corn dogs were yummy! and the chips were devine! :p Abit gutted that I had to pay 30p extra for a blob of mayo. For dessert I got me the waffle with ice cream. Good choice!Time out voted them best budget award, however you do get what you paid for (in portions). I wouldnt mind going there again. Its American food (not like the average dixy chicken or southern fried chicken down the high street that claim to serve American food) The Diner is the closest it gets to American Diner food

1jDXoXpT3tAAWFHKICpQlA.text: The Diner is an OK attempt at the American diner but in a more clean cut, chain restaurant looking way. It doesn't have the charm and style of the typical diner that I really love. The food is nothing to shout about but the prices are quite reasonable. I don't think I would go back here though as I know a great diner close to where I live. I'd rather just find some tasty, filling and cheap food from The Stables Market round the corner than wait for 30 minutes for my food order. At least in the market you get service with a smile!

photos.caption: Photo of The Diner - London, United Kingdom. The Diner in Camden

51RKaoJKFugGUCRWArTauw.text: Lesson learned, diners in London are not good. This place was pretty gross.  My husband had the Philly steak sandwich and I had the mac and cheese. We split cheese fries. The steak sandwich was gross, the mac and cheese was disgusting. The only decent thing was the cheese fries, and they were honestly average. Never again! The only good thing about this place was the free wi-fi.

KAgzg9kJ_7H5_YJpeHnhVQ.text: Who has just given this place three stars?! Shame on you. I had a delicious cheese burgers which I thoroughly enjoyed,  decently priced, and they even asked me how I wanted it cooked! I had some of my friend's alcoholic milkshake (the kraken, banana ice cream, maple syrup, kraken rum, etc) and it was awesome as well! I tried a taste of a hot dog which was not quite as excellent, but their menu is big enough, and tasty enough, that I see myself coming back here sometime soon!

CBJx8a1lKyp1xfL39z0evg.text: Really happy with the food at the diner. Great to see this British take on American culture. Visitor from California so it was awesome to see hot sauce on the tables and avocados on the menu :-)Facebooked everyone back home about the red white and blue menus with a collection of classic diner food with Mexican dishes thrown in. Definitely not the US attitude toward our cuisine but actually super accurate. Free wifi not working when we were here but that seems pretty standard for London in my very limited experience. Free refills on coffee and outlets in every booth make it a great place to do work.Haven't tried the hard milkshakes but will definitely be back to find out.

YI4jerbQ9M7D_T1ZhAERww.text: Decor... Nice, very diner'esqe, clean and yes you feel like donning a leather jacket and greasing the living hell out of your hair. The staff look awesome. They are all done up in 60s 70s gear and seem to enjoy their roles.The food is ok if you are hungry. If you are looking for the all American experience you may be disappointed. With the effort put into the surroundings you expect the food to match up but it just doesn't make it.Good but not amazing simple American grub that will certainly fill a hole.

o9GJy2spkRTvj1jKH_yqeA.text: You've been to Ruby's right? Ok, perhaps not. Denny's? Perkins? Or how about IHOP, Shoney's, Bob Evans, Big Boy, Waffle House, Cracker Barrel, Eat'n Park, Friendly's, Bickford's, Huddle House, Golden Griddle, Steak n Shake, Ram's Horn, or Village Inn. Perhaps? The Diner proved to be exactly like your average **insert name from above here**, except rather than your usual sightings at the end of a pier or along Route 66, it happens to be tucked away on a side street in the birthplace of punk ... or perhaps where punk has gone to die, I'm never quite sure, but I wanna rock. Just sayin. Authenticity-wise, I was quite impressed -- The Diner was smack dab on target and completely true to it's American roots:-All day breakfast?CHECK-Terribly attempted Mexican food topped with absolutely laughable "salsa?" CHECK.-Bland unremarkable choices that you could make in your own kitchen? CHECK.-Slow service with attitude that they pass off as "50s Kitsch?" CHECK-Uhhh-MAZING desserts? CHECK, CHECK, CHECK PLUS.I applaud The Diner's attention to detail, I really do. And while the food could have been better, as soon as I saw that shakes were being served in soda fountain glasses complete with the excess in a silver shaker, all was right with the World.

lz-jB60dsF4bHtNfVu_ddQ.text: My boyfriend (with a mahusive appetite), teenage daughter (fussy eater) and I (the normal one) ate here tonight. What a joint! Loved it. Retro style burger bar. Not gourmet cuisine by any stretch but gorgeous diner food with generous portions. Bf had the biggest one on the menu with steak burger, pulled pork ( succulent melt on mouth pork) fried egg and cheese. He claims its the best burger he's ever had in UK. Fussy daughter ate whole burger for the first time ever. Staff were lovely, and bill £20 a head for 2 soft drinks each, main and loads of sides.

UvYd_xaCxKSo8AfNb3jtaQ.text: The Diner, my go to place whenever I visit Camden. It's not gormet, it's not fancy, it's a burger bar and a good one at that. It basically does what it says on the tin and you get what you expect.The selection of burgers is good and pretty like the ones you can get in diner's in America from my personal experince. The food is good, quick and filling. It's not good for you, it's a little greasy, but it's tasty and does the job. The menu has some fun things and the usual American and Mexican fair, meatloaf, chilli, breakfasts, hotdogs, milkshakes, lots of sugary desserts and pancakes that are very nommy.The price for central London is decent, burgers hover around the £5 to £8 mark, which I don't think is bad. The sides selection is great and drinks are varied and cocktails fun. Staff always seem friendly and happy to help. All in all a nice place to grab a quick bite, a decent American diner.

cx7EkOzfsWif_WQ7kxA0Og.text: Having heard a lot about this place, and being a big fan of the American Diner experience, I was looking forward to my first meal here. I had it last Saturday (15/1/2011) and was very underwhelmed.For a start, I hated the music - What kind of American-style diner plays Beautiful South? Often the atmosphere and music is the best part of a diner but in this area The Diner failed spectacularly.The biggest problem was the service, which in my eyes was nothing short of a disgrace - A team of bored, non-chalant, uncaring women who seemed to take eye contact as some sort of massive task and were happy doing as little as possible and getting each customer out of the door as quickly as possible. We stood patiently by the 'please wait to be seated' sign for nearly fifteen minutes but I'm not really sure why we bothered, considering the amount of people who barged in past us to the empty tables to no reaction from the waiting staff. Eventually we just sat ourselves down with no problems, but not sure why the sign needs to be there. The only interaction we had with the waitresses was to place our order, receive our order and pay our bill - No one asked us how our meal was, if there was anything we needed or anything like that and I had to flag down three separate waitresses just to get the free refill on my coffee!The food was fine, if a little overpriced. I had a very nice bacon-cheeseburger with some well-prepared fries and I can highly recommend the coffee, which was terrific. When paying we did leave a tip but, par for the course, were not thanked and didn't even get a goodbye.If you want a proper Diner experience, with fantastic serive and proper decor including music, I'd recommend Ed's Diner. The Diner's food is standard as far as diners go but the service is lousy. I look forward to exploring Camden's resturants more but doubt I'll bother checking in here again.

eD2YpIeO_awOzZTAhqglZg.text: The Diner has its moments service was slow but friendly. All in all the music was cheesy matched the decor. But loved the milkshake and the British attempt to remake a retro American diner.

mLjk9njkcjHBTiVIwVQz1Q.text: Dined here for breakfast with a friend of mine right as they opened at either 10-11am.Everything looked good visually. The place was clean and the staff was polite.We ordered an omelet and pancakes to share.It all tasted just like home---what more do you need to know?Suggestion to the Diner---open earlier! Most Americans don't want to eat breakfast at 10am unless it's a weekend.

Cm0UFwO5kuK2fbij2IWuDA.text: This is a nice place to hang out.  We had alcoholic milkshakes on a rainy day, and boy did they hit the spot!Also, the sweet potato fries were delicious!

Us1uTtfthkzp0kj5eGAD2A.text: My dining partner and I come here on average once a month for the pancakes. If you come when the place isn't overly crowded, the pancakes are top notch, as is everything else we've tried here (all breakfasty foods, I will admit). When it's very busy, though, the food is a bit hit and miss. The last time we were here, I got toasted corn bread with smashed avocado with chili peppers and two poached eggs on top. And a few bites of his pancakes. It was absolutely delicious, and will likely be my new staple - when I don't have those pancakes. Speaking of the pancakes, it's the plain buttermilk pancakes that are the best. I got blueberry pancakes once and was disappointed to see that it's just the plain pancakes, served with a blueberry sauce instead of maple syrup. When I think blueberry pancakes, I think blueberries in the batter - but maybe that's just me?

rCUr-8WLOw3IvBWd8RYSAQ.text: In one word: Meh.If Yelp would offer the possibility to have half degrees. then this place would totally deserve a 2.5 stars. This place is simply so and so, mediocre, half good half bad. Did you got the idea!?After a line of ten minutes advertised as a 5 one (but well that's ok, when you are in shoreditch you behave as shoreditch people, in one word... you wait!), we sat at this typical american diner (the fact that I'm speaking as I've ever been to a real diner is just hilarious!), you know the kind of places you find in any New York located movie.. I like the idea, a bar, diner sofas, blackboard with the menu... this sort of stuff!We had burgers, fries and salads. Just mediocre. I mean, nothing bad, but I nothing good, I had the diablo, advertised as signature dish, but in the end it's just a cheeseburger with bacon and jalapeno.. damn this is everything your cook can do? for 9 pounds it's a bit too easy... the salad was a bit too short on everything but salad, yes nice try my darling, but do you really think I'm THAT stupid!?!The only reason for going to this place is probably the milk-shake: a bit expensive but definitely good!With the choice of places in Eastern London where to have a burger, go somewhere else... but if you want a milkshake during afternoon then.... road to the diner!!

nauOTx2_dh8RkREJlZADwA.text: I like the food here. It plays on the cool American diner vibe. Comfortable booths and pictures of California grace the walls. I've been here now twice for breakfast and once for dinner. I prefer their breakfast menu. So why 3 stars and not higher? The service here- though nice- is very slow. They simply do not hire enough staff to cover how busy this place is. I waited once 45 minutes for my bill. Not cool! Also- if you want to grab someone's attention after you have your food that is going to be a difficult one- as there is simply not enough staff to cover all the tables!The food is true to American style on most dishes. I've went twice for breakfast.  I got the blueberry pancakes which were good but it's regular pancakes covered in a very thick blueberry sauce (may want to ask for light on the sauce). The second visit I got the veg. breakfast burrito which was very good and comes with black beans & guacamole. You should also order some hash-browns as the burrito is pretty small and you need something to absorb the spice. I will the veg breakfast burrito again if we go back. My husband gets the lumberjack breakfast and really enjoys it.For dinner I was not blown away by the food. I got the halloumi bun and felt it was covered in sauce. Don't like the combo of pesto & hummus. Pick one! I'd definitely ask for your sauce on the side with that dish. Diner fries with sauce were okay but tasted too much of sugar in the sauce. Wouldn't order those fries again.I'd definitely come back here for breakfast but just make sure you ask for the bill as soon as they put the food down to eliminate the long wait afterwards.

u7O5sslsOKgNuw4RXgylmQ.text: The atmosphere was amazing and menu read everything I would want from an American diner. I was yearning for a taste of home. It was sadly not that. Someone at my table watched her breakfast sit in the window for 15 minutes, while mine wasn't bad in flavour, it wasn't what was promised on the menu description and the hot dog that was ordered by another was just obviously under a heat lamp as well. American-style service was not part of the theme. We entered and staffed seemed  nonplussed that we were there. After we sent back the lumberjack breakfast that was cold they gave us back the same plate heated up again (under a heat lamp no doubt) the eggs were curling at the edges where they had been over lamp-heated and dried out. I know image is a lot and when people are talking about the diner in their reviews they think the atmosphere is cool and the menu reads well, but I really noticed wasn't those things but the mediocre food. Many will keep going here but I hope that they bring the standard of their food higher. Another reason why I question chains that grow so quickly because they have a trendy vibe not a renown menu.

i_TNcLOcy0rKJ-AQwrMX-Q.text: No taste dinner. The onion rings do not contain onions... The turkey special burger with cranberries is dry without cranberries... To avoid.

Je4cs03ZS1-NTACQscoYFQ.text: One of the only places where you can get breakfast all day. Portions are huge, food is pretty good. Food is actually American-style rather than fake American-style. They have Cholula on every table so you can spice everything up. Service tends to suck, though, but I guess that's pretty common.

GsjQb2OlCcylbLH6-3J55A.text: Looks like a cool American diner, done properly with red and black booths. No normal tables. Food served in baskets and only traditional American grub on offer.Unfortunately the actual service and food did not live up to the decor...Took over an hour to get our food so I had to leave while others finished up to get my train on time. Staff seemed to look right over us when we wanted sauce or drinks.The actual food was OK. I had a hot dog and half the bread was stale, booo.Meat loaf sandwhich, chilli and bagel were all passable but not enough to salvage this place.

U8PiD1CcP4NnULAXddydsw.text: Return visit to The Diner prior to hitting the market.  Daughter swears their 'mac and cheese' is the best there is.  I decided to try the Big V dog with intrepidation.  Veggie sausages that I've had in the past have been awful, usually macedonian vegetable mix formed into a sausage shape!  I had a hot dog  bun with two veggie hotdogs and ketchup and mustard drizzed across the top!  it was delicious!  We had to have a coke float each - I remember making these as a teenager when I worked in a Wimpy bar  and very few places I've been to serve them!  It's traditional American food but it's tasty so, if you've never been, well worth a visit!

mJJqh2JFliGbBBIyazAPqw.text: This place is the perfect breakfast diner, an all-day breakfast diner. Hearty American pancakes with bacon, eggs and maple syrup makes a classic meal and these guys do them well. You feel stuffed by the end. The burgers on the other hand, though there is provide a lot of variety, tend to be a bit over cooked and greasy, sitting heavy in your stomach. And once again sides are not thrown in with the pricing so you're going to end up paying more than £10 to get the whole meal. I've eaten here sometimes when sides alone have been sufficient though and the chilli cheese fries are great. To top of the diner experience you've got a whole bunch of sugary desserts and milkshakes (which you can spice up with some bourbon). There's also some good American beers on the menu that aren't easily found in shops, so take advantage!

Vct3JZcg1puVh_m1NrDCrQ.text: The Diablo Burger - Popped in here for a pre gig meal, and it pretty much ticked all the boxes, we only had a hour to get some grub and the service didn't let us down, we waited 5 minutes for a seat then sat down and ordered a couple of beers, good to see them stock the local Camden beer, which is very tasty.So onto the food, i ordered 'The Diablo' burger which is there 'special' burger which consist's of a 8oz patty made with chuck, sirloin, filet and rib served with bacon, american cheese and all the other trimmings you'd expect all mounted on a soft brioche bun with a spicy tangy burger sauce, they asked me how i wanted it cooked which is always a plus, i opted medium/rare as i like a little pinkness to my burger, when it arrived i was like 'WOW' look at this beast! I sunk my teeth into the soft bun then it hit me, the crunch of the pickle/onion, then the cheese and bacon, then the show stopper, the patty, then i gave the groan, i was in heaven, my brother looked at me like I was some kind of nut job that had just escaped broad-moor, but i didn't care, each mouthful was lush, I also had some wet fries and mac 'n' cheese to ride shotgun with my burger, tasty but nothing to write home about. My Brother had the Kansas Dog, which was a beef frank, topped with cheese and pulled pork, that also looked amazing.I will be coming back here soon to sample more meaty goodness,

photos.caption: Photo of The Diner - London, United Kingdom. The Kansas Hot Dog.
Photo of The Diner - London, United Kingdom. The meaty goodnes inside  The Diablo Burger
Photo of The Diner - London, United Kingdom. The Diablo Burger.

Qj7cnphnAjo6Yxp4PksWZA.text: As I entered the Diner, It was immaculate!The customer service was great. But lets get to the food. Corn Dogs: I don't know what Corn has got to do with this food....Er yeah considering it just a frankfurter in a thin bready wrapping (can't even describe it). But its alright with tomato ketchup.Potato Skins: With bacon and melted cheese tasted good if the cheese was a bit more mature, it would of toped it off for me.Mac & Chees: Ive had Caribbean, Ive had Waitrose ready made, Ive even made my own but NOTHING prepared me for the taste that was about  to enter my mouth. It was moist...creamy and cheesy and soooo good. I had to save that one to last just to savour the taste.This place is cheap and and its going in my £10 London list. So yeah I will bop here again just for Mr MC.

photos.caption: Photo of The Diner - London, United Kingdom. Corn dogs, Mac&cheese,Fries and potato skins with bacon & cheese.
Photo of The Diner - London, United Kingdom. Corn dogs.

CpvvsL0mVwbD0HIBFzl9QQ.text: I liked this place. Great American diner option. Went here on a night out before hitting the Electric Ballroom in Camden. Great location - close to tube and the venue. Had a tasty burger, chili cheese fries (!!), and the drinks were great as well. Also, the breakfast menu looked killer.Would happily go back when in the area.

xu64OoaLhq2HlgMNmCEWig.text: I took a bite of my burger, and then a friend's Diner Dog and then the chili cheese fries and then I had to make an admission: it taste good. It really do. And I bet the breakfast taste best of all.I mean, you could do better for yourself in probably 50 or so of the US states, and spend less, but it DO taste good. And it's not US-cheap, but it's definitely Camden-reasonable (Unlike CERTAIN ByUrGoEnR [wasn't that clever] joints).I mean, comparing the meal to its London-diner brethren I kinda wanna get all "Yay! I'm A Fan" about it....but look at the last sentence featuring "I mean"; upbringing in the land of economy diners [and the fact that fries are à la carte geez c'mon now] is just stapling my feet to the ground here.

26UNKL6ZSUmXZgWzxefG3Q.text: Im always a fan of The Diner. Generally speaking they make solidly good food. The Chilli and Breakfast Waffle are always a win. and the Breakfast burrito. and the milkshakes... but these dare all things i have said before.Being that this one is in Camden, i expected it to be filled with annoying kids, but the clientele were just normal residents like me, and the staff still quirky and friendly.yeah my food wasn't as hot as it should have been, and oh man, the wall i was sitting next to needed a good wipe down (read: food stuck to it), but I'm not complaining that loudly.till next time, my dear.

LfZWBNh5r4aTQWgJWbmMEw.text: OK, you get it - it's meant to look American, but we all know the truth... a bit naff and themey.That said, the reason I love this place is that not many people seem to know about the roof terrace. I've probably just ruined that, right? Downstairs is boring for those that have actually eaten in a diner in America, but come last weekend when the sun finally showed itself, a fab place to dig in for the afternoon. We had a sun-trap table in the corner and, yes, the service could be faster but was very pleasant. Dishes range from £6 - £10 ish for budgers, burritos, huevos rancheros, omelettes and pancakes etc.Go for the lumberjack breakfast - not often, mind. Your arteries might kill you in rebellion.Speaking of rebellion, watch the obligatory service charge too.And don't tell anyone American about the price. My ex laughed his socks off when I said I'd been drinking Lone Star at £3.30 by the bottle when his Texas local charges $4.00 a jug!!!!

photos.caption: Photo of The Diner - London, United Kingdom
Photo of The Diner - London, United Kingdom

lR8Uavbj2CwL2cXZPWHP8Q.text: I would have only given it 2 stars if the waiter hadn't been so damn cute and friendly...I got the 'new york' cheesecake - that couldn't be less new york if it tried...it was that yucky bog standard cheesecake that you see in every cheap restaurant!The milkshake was pretty good though. I wanted vanilla but they didn't have any vanilla ice cream?? So I had a strawberry one which was pretty thick and yummy and had actual strawberries in it too!!that was dinner tonight! typical scot ;)

a86Rr7ybuewHDWVRhsBq0w.text: I love the concept of a all day breakfasts and late night diners. I love  booths. I love friendly waitress who sit down with us whilst taking our orders. And to add to mix, a roof top terrace is dandy (although it shuts at 8). So far so good - a US style diner, not overly strewn with Americana and memorabilia. Similarly with the other The Diners in London I am less impressed with the execution. A visit was due, after a few evening drinks at the bar opposite. The boy found himself hungry and myself and Vicky L craved *healthy* milkshakes. The boy's food arrived - a decent-ish looking vegetarian mushroom burger. The fries we ordered with our drinks came - an impressively healthy sized basket of chips. However the raison d'etre of our visit, the milkshakes never materialised. We waited and waited. I kept hearing the blender go whizz. "We're next" I thought excitedly. Each time "thunk" sank my heart time as the waitress kept serving booths behind us. We saw just one lady making milkshakes, so thought perhaps there was a backlog. Slowly the fries diminished in number. We planned to fill ourselves on the shakes, not the chips. Vicky L rightly coined our sentiment as "We wanted chips with our shake, not shake with our chips".  She also had a bizarre plan of dunking hot chips in cold milkshakes, which went out of the window. Slowly it dawned on us they had forgotten our milkshakes but it was too late, most of the blooming chips had gone.  When I pointed to the waitress they had missed something, she asked us what we wanted to do, Much to my boyfriend's intense embarrassment I suggested we get the drinks on the house. I must have spent far too much time with my Mum's boyfriend who once after some intense food waiting negotiated (to my shame at the time) a whole meal for free. I am actually surprised our waitress didn't automatically offer us the drinks complimentary, but she obliged when asked with no quibbles. However my boyfriend's reaction made me think I had overstepped mark with my cheek, and added extra guilt with my shake.Despite the additional bitterness caused by poor service and embarrassing interactions, it was still thick, yummy chocolate and peanut butter shakey-goodness  Minor quibble, it could have done with a wider straw as it kept getting clogged up but I think I've moaned enough in this review.Vicky L also pointed out a filth encrusted lamp on our table, and most the toilets were out of loo roll. A lady in one of the toilets kindly passed me a few sheets of paper, and then said "I really should go get some loo roll - I work here!". I never saw her go back in.I wasn't super impressed with The Diner, but overall it was OK. As a late night dinning spot it does mostly what it intends to, and in the right state of mind I would go again.

Rh0tLcavbFsGuJy_xzqmYw.text: Mehh.  After a night out, my friends and I went looking for a place where we could pig out  on some good American grub like we used to back in the states.  I think my friends were happy, but I wasn't satisfied with my mea.  I ordered vegetarian huevos mutolenos, the onion rings, and an oreo milk shake (yes, I am aware that that is a shit ton of food).  The huevos mutolenos was enormous and the tortilla was soggy at the bottom.  The onion rings were decent, but the onion to batter ratio was off (too much batter).  Finally, my milkshake MY MILKSHAKE was barely a shake.  It was watery and had bits of oreo floating around.  Good ambiance tho :)

-YkR63SLY-8_RPDZkwJWlQ.text: We came here several times for breakfast and enjoyed the food, the environment, the music.  They were also very kid friendly (we have a two year old toddler).  We would go back again.

photos.caption: Photo of The Diner - London, United Kingdom

y2u_xWe8VdiZNaADf72Z4Q.text: No complaints! Food here was good, and the fries were especially delicious. We sat outside and had great service!

photos.caption: Photo of The Diner - London, United Kingdom

weKh2lI4yjn_Ba4yii2fVA.text: It was a raal treat to have this on the pancake day and staff was also in very cheery and excited mood which added to the experience of joyfulness.

photos.caption: Photo of The Diner - London, United Kingdom. Peanut Butter and Jelly Pancake with Fresh Orange Juice  #pancakeday #treat

dv5Tk7_x0kcARwhB_7nfoQ.text: That was the best veggie burger I have had in a long while. Made with a very decent patty and halloumi that was perfectly cooked. Service was great and the beer menu is well stocked.

photos.caption: Photo of The Diner - London, United Kingdom

O2H7q1jGmKrxyUUwR17j7Q.text: Disappointing. I had the double dirty burger. The bun was just a random bun from a supermarket, not american style at all.The patty's were very boring, just beef mince with little flavouring. Most american patties have seasoning in from salt and pepper as basic.The patties were also over cooked so they were crunchy on the outside and fairly dry in the middle.It was edible and to be fair they gave me a discount because they could tell it was badly done.But overall, these are burgers i or anyone can make at home, there's nothing special or even american about them.I was also confused because the double burger is two 4oz patties at £7.99 and the single cheeseburger is 1 8oz patty at £9. My maths might be off but the double and the single are the same amount of meat.

4c6XCVt4f65vBY1zt3Q57Q.text: As Americans we only met here for breakfast with our big group. But omg we ended up there almost every morning! My husband LOVED the pancakes with eggs and I LOVED the burrito with chorizo and guac! The staff was attentive and friendly. So fun to see someone take the diner experience, and IMPROVE it!

18_BVxgEYqUWSlsEW2qT_A.text: Slowly collecting all The Diners. On this occasion I had a Californian burger (with avocado) with extra bacon (cause bacon) which was superb. Tried the Sweet Potato Poutin to start as I was sharing with a friend, which was nice but not enough cheese. Good service though slow for food to arrive. Wait staff were lovely

photos.caption: Photo of The Diner - London, United Kingdom

dGgi6r-Gbp7IKl9cRvV30A.text: I expected to hate The Diner but I actually was quite impressed. The menu felt indeed like an American one (not just what Brits think Americans eat), the service was fantastic with a super sweet and attentive waitress (very American style as well) and the prices were ok.I had the corndog and a side of cheese fries. The corndog turned out to be two (a steal for £5) and the cheese fries were perfect. Not the healthiest meal I've ever had, but that's diner food for you. Beers were fairly expensive (esp for being bottles not draughts), but wine was good and fairly priced.

-lcVktI5kJGwBKor5Y5foQ.text: Tasty American style food, with a twist!Burgers are spot on and fries, well you will be served with a lot but it's good to share.The starts we had chicken wings and that wasn't too bad.My friends and I had sweet potato chips and normal regular fries.Pancake small stack was a lot but was really light and fluffy.Good day/night out with friends, causal scene, with banging old Skool hip-hop jams in the background.I would score this restaurant 7 out of 10.

photos.caption: Photo of The Diner - London, United Kingdom. Fluffy pancake
Photo of The Diner - London, United Kingdom. Bacon and beef burger 8oz
Photo of The Diner - London, United Kingdom

CiUHb5H0cIrveikUwS4Tmg.text: So, there has been a proliferation of these American-style diners and The Diner is the slightly older kid on the block. It looked like a good place for a quick bite in the Camden area, and I am a sucker for that American retro-diner style they have going for them with red booths and flashing neon signs. Their menu is HUGE. They have everything, from hot dogs, burgers and plate of ribs to all day breakfast items like french toast and egg florentines. You could probably think of anything American and find it on their menu. It really leaves you spoilt for choice. Naturally, I go straight to the pancake menu. I get the red velvet pancakes with cream cheese frosting and my friend goes for the classic blueberry ones. The pancakes come in stacks of three which is a good portion size. We also order waffle fries because who doesn't like waffle fries??! I wanted to love the red velvet pancakes, I really did. It looked amazing but the flavor just fell flat. It tasted like dry pancakes with red food colouring which was a shame because the cream cheese frosting was not too bad. On the other hand, the blueberry ones were glorious. They were fluffy, warm and bursting with fresh blueberries that it made the red velvet one pale even more in comparison. The waffle fries were tasty too although we had to keep repeating our request for more sauce. The portion is large and was very filling. The tap waters were also slow to come although our restaurant was less than half-full. A bit of a disappointing service to be honest. All in all, The Diner does a passable attempt at recreating the traditional American diner. The atmosphere is spot on but some of the food misses the mark in a big way.

xLIrnelE2PwBgPZ75Vgk4g.text: The only thing that lets this restaurant down is the service. As we arrived, we were told that there would be a wait. Sure, no problem... but we were told by the surly waiter at the door that we were not permitted to wait inside and so would have to stand in the freezing cold until summoned. Unimpressed, we left to go somewhere else, but soon changed our minds when our stomachs dictated that we really wanted to try some of their lovely varied menu.As we returned, we were greeted by someone else that immediately led us to a table... right by the door where an icy wind kept us shivering. We were eventually allowed to move to another table, but only after we were asked twice within 5 minutes if we were ready to order - and were given a strange look when we said that since we had literally just been seated, we were not ready to eat.After that strange debacle, we ordered our food and then waited a reasonable length of time. When the food arrived, we were blown away. I found myself to be eating the best Philly cheesesteak that I had ever eaten. All in all, I would definitely recommend this place, purely based on the food. If the food wasn't as good as it was, I would be saying to avoid this place like the plague.

eastFdQBa00-1GXf-ScH-A.text: Called here for dinner, and was really pleased. First up this place is an American Diner in Camden. The menu, decor and music all represented the diner experience that have had in the US. I ordered a Burger & sweet potato fries & a diet coke. The food was decent enough and arrived within good time. I would recommend you trying this place out.

iQpxmxoNfOF2F_TmpKJt5Q.text: It was just after noon and my colleague suggested getting some food. He has issues with gluten so it's always fun trying to find something he can eat that won't make him swell up.We also failed to agree on what meal it was, he was adamant it was still appropriate to eat breakfast, whereas I think 12ish is definitely lunch time!I jumped on Yelp! to see where we could order an all day breakfast and a burger and found The Diner!We sat in a booth and ordered some drinks. I made the tragic mistake of thinking a milkshake would be a good choice. After having an amazing Oreo shake at Byron, I ordered one from here expecting the same creamy goodness. It was super thick and possibly the sweetest, most sickly thing I've ever 'drank'. It also had a huge dollop of toffee/caramel sludge in it which kept clogging up my straw!The worst thing about the milkshake though was that it totally ruined my appetite. My burger with pulled pork and bbq sauce was unfinishable. It wasn't a brilliant burger either, the patty was all beef-no seasoning, and the bun was a soggy mess. I also ordered a side order of sweet potato fries, which were good, if a little salty, and would have been great to dunk in my milkshake if it arrived at the same time. (If you don't dunk fries in your shake, you're doing it wrong!)I'd probably go back again, but not in a hurry.

photos.caption: Photo of The Diner - London, United Kingdom. Sweet potato fries!
Photo of The Diner - London, United Kingdom. Sickly much?

DsKLgg_1ZSTxe_PNYXAE0Q.text: The Diner varies in quality, but the Camden branch is my fave.The shakes are second only to Byron. Yet the Diner makes up for that with the selection far outmatching. Their Pistachio shake for instance is just pure bliss.The food varies, but one thing you can sure of is that the diner will continually renovate it's menu to clear out things that don't work and introduce things that will ignite the food world. The DCB I had recently is one of those things. It stands for Diner Chicken Burger and it's a moist piece of buttermilk fried chicken topped with bacon, blue cheese, coleslaw and pickles. It's a masterpiece.Surely, if they can re-create more burgers touching this epicness they will have me as a customer after many more gigs in Camden Town.

photos.caption: Photo of The Diner - London, United Kingdom. The DCB, Gravy Fries and Philly Cheese Steak Sandwich

6tECaJAOv5MDJKc4CPXx5A.text: I love any restaurant that serves a reuben sandwich! For those of you who haven't a clue what the greatest American sandwich is... then go and order a reuben sandwich at The Diner! You won't regret it!I like diners... and I think the UK should have more of them. The fact I came here after a large night out.... I paid massage homage by ordering large! I ate everything on my plate, but my friend who's hangover experience had turned in the wrong direction was unable to eat much. His loss! Nice place, nice menu. I recomend!

--Z_2CyltkXt0F9WhiQ-ig.text: Always get the same drink when I come here - vanilla ice cream with Peanut Butter and Nutella milkshake, and it's absolutely freaking divine. Love it. And if that's not for you, they do lots of other 'shakes...with alcohol as an additional extra. The food here is also great, and they do gluten free buns for those of you out there that are allergic/intolerant or just on a health kick. The menu covers all your standard diner burgers alongside breakfast foods (including some Mexican influenced items) The service was also great and friendly. Definitely coming back.

j6PnbwuG3nHMsILBt4CaIA.text: This place has all the makings of a great diner but somehow didn't quite live up to the hype! I've been here three times now and every time they didn't have something. The first two times it was biscuits and the third it was ice cream (which was a bit amiss considering they serve milkshakes and desserts!)The food is great but I'd say it's on the expensive side for what it is. It's very touristy but it's good for brunch if you're out with friends.

i5m2Mh_jxeOQrAGXP0S3rg.text: Good selction on food on offer. I ordered the fried chicken burger which was crispy on the outside and the fillet itself was thick and tender. The fries were tasty and the veggie breakfast burrito was lovely and very filling!

U6Kmpbd3SNVAyp2_-0xExA.text: Not the greatest place to go ... Place was overpriced even though they was suppose to be a roof top place to eat they told us it was closed and the food was literally taste less

h1MEmaeR8cbMW4LJWbFWbQ.text: Overpriced and under serviced.  Drinks, at 2,50 per, were full of ice...Avoid this and go to the  Elephants Head or Caffe Nero across the street
